episode_title: Political Pressure on Entrepreneurs: Should You Take A Stand?

ï»¿Nikolas Hulewsky (00:00.782)
Let me just mic check here real quick.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:09.582)
all right. I I said it, I said it kind of as we got started on the pre-call. So weird yesterday was a weird day for me to see, Charlie Kirk got assassinated. And, all I can think about was the fact that this 31 year old young man, whether you agree with him or don't agree with him, was murdered in front of his wife and his two kids. One of them being a year old and the other one being three years old and the fact that they're going to grow up without.


a dad and like, I felt very similar to the way that I felt when some of these other mass shootings have happened, like the Uvalde shooting at the elementary school. There's just like a visceral reaction to the fact that somebody has gotten so animated and so angry that they choose to go to violence as opposed to debating ideas, which is kind of what our country was founded on.


And it's been heavy. It's been a heavy day for me. And I've also been thinking about kind of what this means for the next day, week, month, year, because I go onto Twitter or I onto social media or Blue Sky or threads. And it's all anybody is talking about. Some people are like, congratulations, you just radicalized me. I'm now a radical right. Some people on the left are


celebrating the fact that this guy was murdered. And then there's people in the middle who were just like, what does this mean? Like what is going on? Why is, does there seem to be so much more political violence? We had an assassination and kidnapping plot against Gretchen Whitmer in Michigan. That's her name, right Chris? it Megan Whitmer? Gretchen. We had the president survive an assassination attempt. We had those...

Yeah, great.

state legislators in Wisconsin that I think it was Wisconsin that were murdered. Now Charlie Kirk gets murdered. It's like, what, what is going on? There's, you know, it's a lot of people just trying to understand what is going on. And I don't know, I'm kind of in the, in the same spot as well. I'm just trying to understand what does this mean for us? Um, not as, not just as a country, but just as, as parents and family members and friends moving forward. Um,


It feels like there's a visceral reaction to this. And I've seen a lot of entrepreneurs in particular, like taking a stand and this is not new that taking a stand is not new. But it's almost like we're seeing it draw out more and more like employees want to see their owners or entrepreneurs. Issue a message or take a stand or we know that Gen Z and millennials want to see that more than older generations. But then you see the backlash where somebody does.


quote unquote, take a stand and Bud Light is boycotted because they hired this Dylan Mulvaney or the MyPillow company aligns really closely with Trump. I'm sure their employees loved it, but then they see sales just freaking tank. And I think a lot of entrepreneurs are probably sitting there like, not just scared about the future for themselves and their family and their kids and their communities, but also like, how do I, how do I navigate these waters? Like, what is the best step for us to take? So.


Trenton (03:33.4)
Yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:33.516)
I don't know if that's even a good question or way to articulate it, but I'm just kind of stewing over this thought right now of as an entrepreneur, how do you navigate these waters moving forward?

Yeah. Yeah. That's what I saying. It hit me as well. I actually didn't really know who he was, but seeing him as a dad and a husband and someone that was just trying to have conversation, controversial or not, really hit me and hit a lot of people. I think that one of the things that was striking is social media was hard to be on yesterday because of that. And that kind of evolved quickly from shock to uncertainty to anger and outrage.


Nikolas Hulewsky (04:11.169)
Anger.


Trenton (04:12.566)
Yeah, and a lot of business owners that I know in all kinds of different businesses, almost every single person seemed to come out and say something. But what surprised me was to see how harsh some of the stances were or how intense some of their stances were. You've just turned me into a radicalized right or like you said, somewhere celebrating. I think I'm curious about what's going to happen from here too.


Back in like 2020, we had Black Lives Matter and we had some pretty heavy political movements happen back then. In the teens, we had it as well. we started to see businesses take stands and business owners, that's more importantly, business owners take stands on the different sides. And it really polarized and either drew people in or pushed people out.


I don't know if every business owner thought through or cared about the ramifications. And oftentimes these business owners would go with what was popular, the thing that was going to be the most popular and give them the least amount of friction. And I can go into some stories myself of some things that we dealt with as business and as a business owner for employees and customers when they wanted to see us take stands on certain things.


But I'm very curious to what's going to happen because there's some people now that are swearing that they're going to go out and, you know, be one way or the other and be very political going forward and maybe even more than that.

Especially with companies that are founder-led brands, where the founder is out.

which almost every, and almost every company needs to be that or is that like there's a CEO or a founder or someone at the top that really is that the face of that company. Nikolas Hulewsky (06:17.378)
Well, it's hard to Chris and I have talked about this a lot, like on the one side of things, I do want to see someone who's a leader stand up and say, this is what I think, or this is what I believe, right? Because then I think, cool, then they'll attract the people that agree with them or like then they'll attract their tribe, et cetera. But then the flip is, I love talking to people of all different walks of life. And so I don't like the idea of siloing into, well, I just go to Twitter, which you know,


for my conservative takes and I go to blue sky for my liberal takes and I go to, you know, this business for conservative stuff and that business for liberal stuff. multiple companies.

ostracized or discriminated against. It doesn't make me a difference. But I mean, I don't know, what are you guys doing in your business? Like Trin, you've been in some of these, like have you had employees that want you to take a stand or be thoughtful about that stuff?

And so we had dozens of questions of what our stance was on everyone can see it.


And I think what we did was just true to us. We weren't thinking about what is this going to mean for the business as we take a stand, but we just said we're supportive of Black Lives Matter and, you know, completely against any sort of police brutality or anything like this. And it was just the stance that made the most sense to us and was true to what we felt.

And this is a point where almost every business I felt was saying something as well, but we were in a meeting where they're asking us to say something. I did have one more instance happen.

Yeah.

It's like, this is an emotional time for people. And I think you can make the space to acknowledge that. I think that's something that a leader should do.


I don't believe that because I, and maybe this is the idolization of business leaders in America, like why are we even asking what the business leader thinks? But it's not my job to be the spokesperson for our political stance on our business. Like the business doesn't have a political stance. and are feeling like, man, it's just a tough day, like because of X, Y, and Z what happened. And it's like, that's what you do. We used to do around the water cooler, but to me that is the leader's job. It's not my job to be the voice of my opinion.


Nikolas Hulewsky (14:04.974)
Yeah, I feel that way. I just look at the data and it's like Gen Z and millennials are two to three times more likely to want to hear their leaders say something about what's going on, right? We didn't have 1,000 employees, but we had between 100 and 200 when all of this stuff was happening in 2020.


It felt like every six months there was something else during 2020 that we had to talk about, whether it was COVID or the mask mandate or the vaccine mandate, because I was in healthcare, or, you know, George Floyd, Black Lives Matter. And the way I approached it was like, I was never talking to people about bodily autonomy or systemic racism or, you know, DEI or any or any of these things.


But we had to look at it. What do we talk to people about? It's our core values and our core values were among them, empathy, right? And so we talked about it from that lens where it's like, look, there's a lot going on. We empathize, you know, please be kind, respect each other, et cetera. In the instance with the vaccine mandate and we were a healthcare company, was like, Medicare is mandating this for us. I'm sorry. And if you can't accept that, we will help you exit the organization.


But like, what were we going to do at that point? Screw you, Medicare. And then we just like lose all of our patients and all of our funding. it wasn't, we just, we weren't in a place to take any type of stand against that. So anyway, I, I just think they're, just hard situations to navigate. Cause as a human, want to react, but as a business owner, you're like, how does this affect things downstream?


Trenton (15:52.418)
Yeah, you do need to be thoughtful. I think you gotta let the time settle for emotions. But I had one more too that this was our influencer and sports agency and we represented different influencers that had big, big amounts of influence, millions of followers. One of them was trans and they were upset because this is a time where they felt like trans rights and LGBTQ rights were being really


pushed to the limits and a couple years back and they were upset that some companies were choosing to take neutral stances on this. And then they got upset with us for not advocating for them because of those neutral stances. We had to decide ourselves, do we want to stay neutral or not? This is another one where we stayed kind of true to ourselves and back to you on the value, which was...

that being neutral, like a business is being neutral, should be okay. Like businesses shouldn't have to ship pick one side or the other. And so we kind of took that stance as well. you'll find the alignment with the people that align best with you. And if they need to see that you're political, then they're probably not gonna align. Stay off, that's Chris's philosophy. Okay, we had some other things that happened this week. Chris, it looks like we've had a rate cut and I want you to kind of just go through what's going on right now and what does this mean for small businesses? Like does the Fed even matter for small business?


Trenton (25:03.022)
You


Chris Munn (25:24.771)
Yes, it matters a lot for small business. a little background. 2020, we could start with like 2020 during COVID. Rates were effectively zero, which means banks can borrow money at essentially no interest and then loan it to you at a small percentage higher than that.


And low interest rates mean lower debt payments and debt payments go to worse things like mortgages and business loans and car loans and all sorts of stuff. So with higher, and then after COVID, we obviously had a lot of inflation and the Fed has tried to keep rates high to tame inflation, keep inflation in check.


So now I think inflation is 2.9%, which the goal is always 2%. So I think we'll see rates get cut more aggressively when it gets closer to two, but it hasn't been two in a long time. So we did have a rate cut in September, but we're still super high rates compared to the last five years or so. 10 years, 20 years, super high cuts compared to the last 20 years.


And that affects businesses in a few ways. So I think people going out to buy or sell businesses are seeing different valuations because of the debt service. If someone goes out and bought a business in 2015 and their interest rate was 5 % and now the interest rate is 10%, you know, that can be tens of thousands of dollars a month in increased interest for that business.


So what does that mean? That just means effectively, I can pay you less money, Nick, for your business than I could 10 years ago, because I have to pay the bank a lot more. So Nick might be saying, hey, I want, you know, this multiple on my business. And now I can't pay that because I can't service the debt with the high interest rates. So there's a lot of political pressure to lower the interest rates because it will spur asset buying and selling again.


Chris Munn (27:35.791)
But if we still have inflation that is from an economic standpoint, that is usually not a positive thing. inflation needs to get in check and then hopefully rates can get cut.


Nikolas Hulewsky (27:46.648)
Yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (27:50.19)
So I bought a business in 2020 when rates were effectively zero. And when you go through the process of buying a business, you have to go through underwriting. in order for the bank to give you money to buy that business, they've got to underwrite that business. And they use this almost universally, this one metric called DSCR, your debt service coverage ratio. What that means is if a business is doing $500,000 a year in profit, the bank wants to see at least, we'll call it


1.2 times the amount of profit as they do debt. So in this scenario, let's just make it easy. The max debt that they would lend is $400,000 on a business doing $500,000 a year in profit. And then we know the interest rate, we know the term, we know the amortization period, et cetera. With that $400,000, it's like a max amount that they'll loan. And so in that instance, when rates are near zero, they'll lend you a lot more money.


because the debt service coverage ratio is a lot better because you're paying less debt. Well, when the interest rate goes up, now all of a sudden, the amount that you can afford in debt to buy that business goes way down. so what does that mean? Well, in the early days, in 2020, the reason we saw asset prices go out of control is because we could get a lot of money from the banks because interest rates are really low. We've now seen asset prices contract because they raised rates significantly because people couldn't afford.


Trenton (28:52.814)
.


Nikolas Hulewsky (29:16.994)
that debt surface coverage ratio and it has shown up in the data. So the SBA releases this data in the last year. The amount of delinquencies on SBA loans has increased dramatically. I think it's like a 20 year high from where it's been just because these individuals who bought businesses kind of at the max of their scale all of sudden now because the interest rates are floating, interest rate goes up, payment goes up, they can't afford it. What happens? The bank forecloses on those businesses. So we've definitely seen some of that happening right now.


for small businesses in particular. The SBA is really important, which I just talked about, lines of credit, but then also generally speaking in the economy, being able to hire, being able to find more workers, there's definitely a lot going on. So I am curious to see though what happens with the Fed because our unemployment has been historically low. We're still at historic lows, which is interesting because I still feel like when I talk to small business owners, mean, Trenton, we talked about this in Tribe, it's not like they're...
